pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:0.2_0: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:0.3_0: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:0.4_0: The fourth training rule on acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.10_0: “How can they not announce that there are criminals staying in the monastery?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.11_0: The monks heard the complaints of the Sakyans
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.13_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.14_0: “Well then, monks, I will lay down a training rule for the following ten reasons: for the well-being of the Sangha, for the comfort of the Sangha, for the restraint of bad people, for the ease of well-behaved monks, for the restraint of corruptions relating to the present life, for the restraint of corruptions relating to future lives, to give rise to confidence in those without it, to increase the confidence of those who have it, for the longevity of the true Teaching, and for supporting the training.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.15_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.16.1_0: ‘There are wilderness dwellings that are considered risky and dangerous. If a monk, without first making an announcement about those dwellings, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.17_0: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.18_0: The Buddha has laid down a training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying among the Sakyans at Kapilavatthu in Banyan Tree Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.2_0: the slaves of the Sakyans were rebelling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.3_0: The Sakyan women wished to prepare a meal at the wilderness dwellings,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.4_0: but the slaves heard about this
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.5_0: about the Sakyan women who wanted to prepare a meal at the wilderness dwellings,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.7_0: When the Sakyan women took various kinds of nice food and set out for a wilderness dwelling,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.8_0: the slaves emerged, and they robbed and raped those Sakyan women.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:1.9_0: Soon afterwards the Sakyan men came out, and they got hold of those criminals together with their loot. They then complained and criticized the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.10_0: “Monks, I allow a sick monk, without first making an announcement, to eat staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it at a wilderness dwelling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.11_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.12.1_0: ‘There are wilderness dwellings that are considered risky and dangerous. If a monk who is not sick, without first making an announcement about those dwellings, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.13_0: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.1_0: Soon afterwards a monk in a wilderness dwelling was sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.2_0: People took staple and non-staple food and went to that wilderness dwelling,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.3_0: and so they invited him to eat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.5_0: That monk from the group of six thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.6_0: But knowing that the Buddha had prohibited the eating of staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it at a wilderness dwelling, and being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept it. And being unable to walk for alms, he mised his meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.9_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.10_0: ... The monks who have been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.14_0: if an announcement is made to any of one’s five co-monastics, this is called “without making an announcement”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.15_0: If an announcement is made about anything apart from the monastery or its vicinity, this is called “without making an announcement”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.17_0: if a woman or a man comes to the monastery or the vicinity of the monastery and says, “Venerable, they’ll bring so-and-so’s staple or non-staple food,” then the
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.17_1: If his wife is suspected, but the other monk should tell him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.17_2: If there is dangerous, he should tell him, “Not,” “You should inform him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.18_0: If the person says, “Never mind, it will be brought,” then the criminals are to be told, “People are coming here; go away.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.19_0: When an announcement has been made in regard to rice porridge, and accompanying food is brought, this is called “announced”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.20_0: When an announcement has been made in regard to rice, and accompanying food is brought, this is called “announced”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.21_0: When an announcement has been made in regard to non-staple food, and accompanying food is brought, this is called “announced”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.22_0: When an announcement has been made in regard to a particular family, then when any person from that family brings staple or non-staple food, this is called “announced”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.23_0: When an announcement has been made in regard to a particular village, then when any person from that village brings staple or non-staple food, this is called “announced”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.24_0: When an announcement has been made in regard to a particular association, then when any person from that association brings staple or non-staple food, this is called “announced”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.26_0: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics, the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.28_0: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.2_0: a wilderness dwelling worth five _māsaka_ coins.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.30_0: if the monastery is enclosed, then within the enclosure.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.31_0: If the monastery is unenclosed, then in the vicinity.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.33_0: and was able to walk for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.35_0: And he was not able to walk for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.36_0: If, without making an announcement, one who is not sick receives staple and non-staple food with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.37_0: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.38.1_0: If there has been no announcement, and he does not perceive that there has, and he, not being sick, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, then he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.39_0: If there has been no announcement, but he is unsure of it, and he, not being sick, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, then he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.40_0: If there has been no announcement, but he perceives that there has, and he, not being sick, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, then he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.41_0: If she receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.42_0: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.43_0: If he has been announced, but he does not perceive it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.44_0: If there has been an announcement, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.45_0: If there has been an announcement, and he perceives that there has, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.4_0: in the monastery, or in the vicinity of the monastery, criminals have been seen camped, eating, standing, seated, or lying down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.6_0: in the monastery, or in the vicinity of the monastery, criminals have been seen injuring, robbing, or beating people.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1.8_0: and you have the same kind of perception ...
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.10_0: The fourth training rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.11_0: “Venerables, the four rules on acknowledgment have been recited.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.12_0: In regard to this I will ask you:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.14_0: A second time I ask the Sangha to answer:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.18_0: You will remember it, please remember it; I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.19_0: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.2_0: if there has been an announcement;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.4_0: if he eats the leftovers from where there has been an announcement or from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.5_0: if he receives the food outside the monastery and then eats it inside;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.6_0: There they eat a root, a piece of bark, a leaf, a flower, or a fruit.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.2.7_0: if, when there is a reason, she makes use of post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics;
